Releasing the tention immediately. This likely leads to a tame sicilian. But one where black is cramped and I actually was longing for a tactical game against my lower rated opponent.

Regarding my previous comment, I may should have played ...Bxc6 to be less cramped. Still I wanted to keep as much pieces on the board as possible avoiding drawish tendencies. Now I have a solid center without need to spend time on ...a6.
I regard this a waste of time and would have let the bishop on d7 bound to it's mundane task to keep an eye on c6. I was expecting a kingside attack by f4, g4, g5 etc.

A somewhat tame move but I guess a neccessity because my knight will be under attack soon and the bishop on e7 is in doubled duty of defending Nf6 and Pd6.

Yes, a good square for the queen. My opponent plays this as a positional game alltogether. Quite in alliance with his 9th move. The goal seems to increase pressure on my d-pawn forcing it to move thereby making e5 possible.
I am not that happy with this move anymore. There is an open file so I seize it, was my motiv. The b-pawn could become a target in the long run.
So white doesn't want to abandon the idea of a kingside pawn storm completely. By 12. Qd3 a possible g4 lacks support.
Further backing of the d-pawn.
Finally some pressure against my knight. I have been under way more pressure with black in sicilian positions, so I thought the game to be level right now already.
This is to give my light squared bishop a good post on c6 and it bounds the queen to the protection of c4.

I got lured into positional thinking, ...completely dreaming. Though strategically desireable, this blunderes away my d-pawn.

With the h-pawn on h6 I did not want to take back with my g-pawn.
With the h-pawn on h6 I did not want to take back with my g-pawn.

My blunder has had another negative side effect: Being down in material I wanted to steer the game into drawish channels as soon as possible. Exchanging queens seemed to fit the bill. But now I see 18. ...Da7, 19. Qg3 a4, 20. Bc4 Rxb2 was a better option. I was afraid of the aggressive image of white given after 21. e5 Be7 and then 22. Ne4!

He naturally goes for my pawns.
Luckily I can go for his as well. After b2 falls, c2 will be next.
The point is white needs to spend a tempo on saving is attacked knight.

One of the pawns on c2 and a2 is doomed anyway. So I invest a tempo to save my a-pawn. A draw is within reach.
